bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Donald B. Armstrong, August 20, 1940

div1.p: Hench points out historical errors in documents produced by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. concerning yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Donald B. Armstrong, August 20, 1940
div1.opener:
send for a dozen more copies
Health Heroes--Walter Reed
1926 (Hallock & Tu
Tune)
August 20, 1940
Dr. Donald B. Armstrong
Third Vice-President
Metropolitan Life Insurance Co.
New York City
My dear Doctor Armstrong:
div1.p:
I can't tell you how much I appreciate your bothering to send me the
photographs of the Walter Reed episode, and also the movie strip. I shall make good use
of these, I can assure you, and expect to have slides of some of them made, but will, of
course, credit the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. Could you give me the name of the man
who had charge of the production of this movie strip? I hate to bother you by continuing
this correspondence with you, but I am anxious to obtain the original source of the photo-
graph of Walter Reed, “Walter was an attractive boy”, and the next photograph, “At the age
of seventeen”. I know that the other photographs came from Kelly's book on Walter Reed.

I think you would like to know that in your book “Health Heroes”, as
well as in the movie strip, there are a few historical errors. They are relatively unim-
portant and I quite agree that when teaching the public, one should be permitted a little
license. As a matter of fact, the experiment indicated on page 21 of your pamphlet,
“Health Heroes--Walter Reed” was not quite carried out in that manner. Diagrams 1 and 2 3
never actually took place. Diagram 2 did, of course, but Moran entered the one side of the
Infected Mosquito Building first. No one else had used that side, and so far as the
official record goes, no one used it thereafter. If your historian who made up this pam-
phlet has other evidence, I shall be most interested to hear of it, but it most certainly
isn't in the official record or the Senate Document.

Your artist's concept also of Camp Lazear is just that and nothing
more. There is no river anywhere near Camp Lazear and your artist's concept shows the
Infected Clothing Building and the Infected Mosquito Building separated by this river,
with rather high mountains in the background. I have tramped over the site of Camp Lazear
several times and I am familiar with the lay of the land. It is quite flat.

I realize that these remarks might be interpreted as criticism, and
I pass them on to you merely in case your historians wish to be unnecessarily accurate.
I realize that the films and pictures as they now stand quite serve their purpose. When
I publish my detailed historical researches on this problem, I shall be glad indeed to
send you a copy.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
